While some would suggest that future new arrivals should be bonded to settle inland, the attraction of major cities is greater than just being near the coast. The open community of cities such as Sydney is as powerful a magnet as any beach or harbour view. But while Sydney lays out the welcome mat to the world for the forthcoming Olympic Games, Canberra cannot resist rolling out the barbed wire.

In a case which came to my attention only last week, a constituent told me of his disappointment at the refusal of a visitors visa for his wife's Chinese parents. He had purchased tickets for a number of events, including the table tennis finals, as a surprise for them when they were to arrive in Sydney. You can understand his great disappointment when his adopted country, a country that he loves, a country of which he is so proud, refuses entry to his wife's parents. By any interpretation of the letter informing them of the refusal, it was quite clear that if they were from northern Europe or North America, their visa request would not have been refused. What kind of country have we become, or gone back to being, when we judge people by their race? You can understand how many Australians of Chinese origin are made to feel in this, their own beloved country. How can the many Chinese-Australian residents of Sydney welcome people from all over the world knowing that their own parents are not welcome in this country?

How then, you might also ask, should the descendants of indigenous Australians welcome the world in September? This tale of two cities continues here as well. While the government of New South Wales is prepared to acknowledge the mistakes of the past, to say sorryâto say sorry and mean itâin Canberra it is a different story. Instead of reconciliation, there is confrontation. Instead of an apology, there is a denial. Were I to be a visitor from overseas during the Sydney Olympics I might be shocked at the sight of burning cars, but I would be more disturbed if the faces of welcome were turned the other way.

We hear a lot about the division in our nation between city and country. We hear a lot about what needs to be done to build communication bridges between the city and the bush. But nothing so divides our nation as the gap between those who look out into the world and see opportunity and those who look out and see only threats. Those same people so often display their insecurity in their denial of what has occurred around them. They can only justify their values by applying the most perverse forms of logic and calling the most Australian of values un-Australian.

The Sydney Olympics will be a great success by any measure. The world will come to see that face of Australia that represents the best of the Australian people. If they look down the road to Canberra, they will see the worst.

talk.start.para: âThis year is an Olympic year. It is also a presidential election year in America. I have been quietly observing the American political process, particularly taking an interest in the contest to secure the Republican primary nomination. It struck me that former US President George Bush had taken a relatively hands-off approach to the political point scoring campaign for his son's candidature. It struck me that there has been a lack of obvious attack by Bush Sr against Bill Clinton and his administration. This non-critical approach to the Clinton administration, despite much ammunition, has been a feature of George Bush's ex-presidency.

speech.para: I reflected on this feature of the ex-president and made an analogy of that approach being used in Australia by former prime ministers. The comparison was quite startling. Whilst it is a feature of former presidents to refrain from commenting on current and future administrations in America, we have recently seen in Australia that the same cannot be said of our former prime ministers. In recent weeks, we have seen two of our former prime ministers publicly criticising the Howard government for their stand on certain policy issues. Firstly, Paul Keating criticised the Howard government for Australia's involvement in East Timor and, more recently, Malcolm Fraser publicly criticised Prime Minister Howard over his stance on mandatory sentencing.

This has been damaging to Australia's international reputation, and it caused me to ponder what the role of our former prime ministers should be. There are two trains of thought, when it comes to the matter of what role our former prime ministers should play. There are those who think that we do not utilise our former prime ministers as well as we could and if they are still willing and able they should be able to continue an active public role. There are others who believe that, once a prime minister leaves office, they should retire gracefully.

As we enter the second century of our nation's Federation, it is appropriate that we reflect on what role we expect from our former prime ministers. It is generally agreed by both camps that, regardless of their role, former prime ministers should be provided with public funding to maintain a dignified life and not be forced to engage in activities that are unseemly or inappropriate for someone who has held such an office. Whilst a former prime minister does not continue to receive a salary once they leave office, they are paid a considerable pension as well as being provided with an office and staff, official transport and travel allowances, and security for them and their family. This is a considerable expense to taxpayers. It is interesting to note that the provision of these services for former prime ministers is done as an act of grace; there is no legislative basis to their provision.

In 1996, in answer to a question on notice, we learnt that Sir John Gorton cost taxpayers $104,239; Gough Whitlam, $335,000; Malcolm Fraser, $383,000; Bob Hawke, $221,000; and Paul Keating cost the Australian people $168,000 in less than three months. I firmly believe that this is a justified expense. However, the Australian public are quite within their rights to expect something in return. Former prime ministers, who are being paid by the current government, should not be able to publicly criticise Australia and damage our reputation. Whilst they are encouraged to participate in public debate, there must be some boundaries for what is appropriate for former prime ministers to do once they leave office. However, if we want to engage them more actively, we have to decide how and then provide the funding. In a manner similar to the US, it may be worth while to establish a prime ministerial library to continue generating social policy debate but in a less confrontational and detrimental manner.

I thought the best way of approaching what the role of our former prime ministers should be would be to review post-presidential life compared with post-prime ministerial life. At the moment, there are four living ex-American presidents. They are provided with a salary, office and staff, travel and various other benefits at considerable expense to the taxpayer. They use their profile and considerable influence for a number of causes, both domestically and internationally. For example, Gerald Ford, prior to being ill, travelled the lecture circuit, focusing on Congress-White House relations as well as domestic and foreign policy issues; Jimmy Carter has been known to advocate democracy and human rights all over the globe; Ronald Reagan was active on behalf of many charitable and civic organisations before being overtaken by ill health; and George Bush has been known to publicly advocate the increase of civic duties of Americans. Former American presidents are actively encouraged to continue participating in public debate. They have, as I mentioned, a presidential library system where public funding is made available to maintain presidential libraries and museums built by private donations. These are often attached to a university and double as a centre for public policy.

It is, therefore, not surprising that former Australian prime ministers should also be encouraged to continue a semi-public life. Prime ministers such as Reid, Fisher, Bruce, Fraser and Whitlam have all had a post-prime ministerial life either in overseas high commission roles or with the United Nations. After leaving parliament, Gough Whitlam was appointed as Ambassador to UNESCO and served on their executive board as well as being appointed Chairman of the Australia-China Council. Malcolm Fraser campaigned against apartheid and French nuclear testing as well as being Chairman of CARE Australia since 1987. In contrast to these examples, both Bob Hawke and Paul Keating have become, as former senator John Button described them this year, `fully privatised former prime ministers'. Bob Hawke has done no public work of a sustained nature, although he was recently appointed to the Growing Together summit in Victoria, and he has also published his memoirs. Paul Keating has recently published a book on Australian foreign relations with Asia as well as being very vocal in his criticism of Xanana Gusmao and Jose Ramos Horta. I welcome the Melbourne Age for criticising the disrepute in which Paul Keating has placed Australia with those comments.

Certainty, it is often advantageous having an elder statesman negotiating on behalf of Australians when it is difficult or inappropriate for the government of the day to intervene. This was demonstrated recently when Malcolm Fraser was integral in securing the release of the CARE Australia workers in Serbia in his role as Chairman of CARE Australia. Unfortunately, we are seeing that some former prime ministers feel it necessary not only to take an active interest in contemporary Australian politics but also to comment publicly on the actions of the current administration. These comments are generally benign in effect, but they can have wider international implications from time to time.

This is in stark contrast to the US. Like former prime ministers, former presidents are afforded many benefits and are generally revered as elder statesmen. However, whilst former American presidents do not simply disappear from public life at the end of their term, they essentially refrain from criticising the current administration. There is one exception to that, and I will come to that in a moment. It should not be thought that this is because they have simply not had the opportunity or that there has been no issue worthy of comment. There was ample ammunition that Jimmy Carter could have used to criticise Ronald Reagan's handling of the Iran Contra affair. Similarly, as I have already mentioned, George Bush would have been more than justified in criticising Bill Clinton for some of his actions but refrained from doing so.

Jimmy Carter however, despite all his good work, did stray at one point when he received criticism from the Left and the Right, chastising him for making concessions to dictatorial regimes in his attempts to mediate peaceful resolutions to violent situations and particularly for telling the Haitian junta that he was ashamed of US policy and for negotiating with Bosnian-Serb leaders who were considered war criminals. Despite that, Jimmy Carter, with his new-found public policy ex-presidency model which he is championing, has shown that the goals of peace, justice, human rights, democratic involvement, disease control and improvements in living conditions have led to his ex-presidency being a mark of pride for Americansâa model which perhaps can be used currently by former prime ministers of this country.

However, it would be fair to say that we certainly do not expect our prime ministers to leave office and disappear from public life. They do have a responsibility, nevertheless, to the Australian taxpayers. I say to our former prime ministers that they should remember that they are no longer democratically elected representatives of the Australian public and, accordingly, they should leave the politics of the day to the people of the moment. In this regard they should adopt a more impartial, bipartisan approach to current policy. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Caravan Parks

talk.start.para: âI thought I should respond a little to the honourable member for Deakin. I really thought he was being very precious with his `there should be no criticism of the current government by former prime ministers' approach. Well, former prime ministers are not like that. I thought he was particularly unkind to Prime Minister Hawke and Prime Minister Keating in saying that they had not adopted any public role. It is a matter of record that, under Prime Minister Hawke, notwithstanding that within the Labor Party Prime Minister Fraser was seen as very divisive and very negative, he was supported in his bid to become Secretary-General of the Commonwealthâand would have, I believe, done an excellent job.

speech.para: One thing I do agree with the honourable member for Deakin on is this. We need to better utilise the talents of former prime ministers. It is true that neither Prime Minister Hawke nor Prime Minister Keating has been utilised in this way. I think that is a matter of sadness.

In relation to the Prime Minister's comments that a period of 10 years of autonomy for East Timor would have led to a much smoother transition, I have to completely agree. Whilst I do not want to judge for the East Timorese what is best for them, periods of autonomy where we are building up the skills and the public service base of an area or a province are infinitely better than a rapid changeover from one system to another. So I say to the member for Deakin that I thought he was being a little trite in some of his commentsâalthough I am on his side about utilising much better Prime Ministers Fraser, Hawke and indeed Keating, and I am sure that this government will utilise the services of Tim Fischer when he steps down from this House.

I might point out that the New South Wales government, in its recent conference on salinity had Ian Sinclair, a former Speaker and Leader of the National Party, actually chairing the seminar. That is what the people of Australia want: putting aside party differences and seeking solutions and answers to the big questions that confront the nation.

I want to talk about a meeting that occurred in the electorate of my good friend the member for Greenway on Saturday. This meeting was held at the Riverstone Bowling Club for park residents. I would particularly like to thank Roberta, who was instrumental in doing all the hard yards, and, in particular, Anthony Albanese, the member for Grayndler, who is our shadow parliamentary secretary and has done such a great job to publicise the needs and concerns of these people. I suppose a courage award should go to the member for Mitchell, who also attended and was completely confused about the implications of the impact on the residents. Needless to say, again I would like to acknowledge the fact that he was there and it was good that a government member came along.

What is the problem with long-term residents of caravan parks and residential parks? Well, they are going to be subject to a GST and they are not getting a compensation package. We have the government saying, `Don't worry, Australians, about the impact of the GST. Some little things, as the Prime Minister said, will go up and some little things will go down; but believe what we said at the last election that no-one will be worse off.' These residents are going to be worse off; in fact, they are going to be discriminated against. Let me give you an example. One of the residents who came from Parklea pointed out that $1.5 million in site fees is collected from that park. That is a lot of moneyâthere are a lot of residents. What is going to be the impact on 1 July? The GST is going to be put on half the value of their site fees. That means that those residents are going to contribute to the Commonwealth coffers some $75,000. Now these residents are, I might say, not wealthy residents. They make a lifestyle choice. Often they are pensioners but they choose this form of living basically for a couple of reasons, the first beingâand I would not hide the factâthat it is a much cheaper form of accommodation, and the second being that in these parks there is, of course, a real community spirit that is often missing from our residential suburbs. They are going to be subject to a GST.

The point that I made at the meeting that we had at the Riverstone bowling club was this. Were I a wealthy owner of units along Luxford Road in my electorate, there is no question that there would be no GST on the rent from those units. For those units I provide not only the land but the building and all the common servicesâthat is, keeping them clean and tidy, mowing the lawn and carrying out any other repairs that need to be done. For people in those units and for that $1.5 million, there is no GST levy. A person who is a long-term resident in a park is hiring a piece of ground. They have the water and electricity connected to it, and they pay the charges for it. If there is any mowing to be done, they do the mowing. If there is a garden around it or in it, they look after the garden. They provide the physical infrastructure, the buildingâeither a mobile home or a caravan. Yet for people in that situation the government is providing a 10 per cent GST on half the value. Isn't that discriminatory? Isn't that disgraceful, particularly when you say, `Well, no-one is going to be worse off with a GST'?

I would love some government member to try and explainâas the member for Mitchell valiantly tried to do on Saturdayâthis absurd and discriminatory situation. As I said earlier, I absolutely congratulate the member for Grayndler because he has been all round Australia talking to these people, listening to what they have to say, and he is publicising this absurd situation. We even hear about it from some members of the government. I think the member for Gilmore, Joanna Gash, is on record as saying it is discriminatory. I agree with her one hundred per cent. It is discriminatory. When is the government going to do something about it? When you discriminate against people, it is really saying that if you are in a like situation you have an unlike outcome. That is exactly the situation. If you rent a home or a unit, you do not pay. But if you live in a caravan or in a mobile home, you pay. That is discriminatory.

There can be only two reasons for treating these people as second-class citizensâand this may be the case: a complete lack of understanding by the government of the circumstances of people who are proud to say that they are permanent residents of a caravan park or a mobile home. That is the most charitable explanation. If that is the situation, the government has no reason for not informing itself and for removing this discrimination. The other reason, I suspect, is that it believes that these people do not matter; they do not count and they will not do anything about it. That may be the case, but it is a big risk to take into the next election. I want to congratulate Jim Clark, the coordinator of the Affiliated Park Residents of New South Wales, for coming all the way down from Belmont. Where there have not been units of this organisation established, he is busily setting them up and letting people know just how discriminatory this government is. I ask that, in all fairness, the government remove this discrimination, treat the park residents fairly and change this horrific impact, for which it is not going to compensate them, of having a 10 per cent GST on half the value of the site fees. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Air Force: Point Cook Site

talk.start.para: âMy grievance today relates to the future of the RAAF Williams Point Cook site in my electorate. This site is marked for disposal by the Commonwealth as part of the Defence Efficiency Review and the Defence Reform Program. Point Cook, as anybody familiar with aviation in Australia would know, is a truly historic site. It is the oldest airfield in the world that is still being operated as an airfield and it has many of its original features, including hangars and heritage listed buildings. It was established in 1913 as the Central Flying School, and the airstrip has been in continuous use ever since.

speech.para: To get some perspective about what that means in terms of aviation history, we need to remember that the first-ever manned flight took place on 17 December 1903. So, a mere 10 years later, Point Cook was operating a flying school, and planes have been flying from there ever since. Apart from having history around that length of aviation service, it is of course the birthplace of the Australian Flying Corp and the Royal Australian Air Force. It was the departure point for the first north-south and the first east-west crossings of the continent by air and the first aerial circumnavigation of the continent. Recognising its historic nature, Point Cook is home to both the RAAF Museum and the RAAF Chapel.

One would hope that when a site of this significance is being dealt with by the Commonwealth, particularly when it has been identified as surplus to Commonwealth requirements, there would be a deep consultation strategy engaged in with the aviation community and with the local community as to the future use of the site. Unfortunately, that is not occurring. There has been a great deal of community debate and organisation around the questionânot because the government has come and asked the community what its view is but because the community has determined that it will have its view heard, even if the government is not cocking its ear to listen to what the community has to say. The community recognises that the site has terrific potential as a tourist, education and aviation precinct, a place where you could go and learn about the history of flight and the history of our airforce, go and see the planes in the RAAF Museum and take a flight yourself or at least watch a functioning airstrip in operation. Some of these things are already there at Point Cook, and it is a question of whether or not the government acts in a way which facilitates these things to not only continue but develop over time.

The proposal to turn the site into a mixed education-aviation tourist precinct is well supported by the local community, and a petition which garnered more than 10,000 signatures has already been presented to this place about this matter. Indeed, the Minister for Defence has before him a credible proposal to develop the site as a tourist, education and aviation precinct, that is, a submission from a not-for-profit company called Point Cook Operations Ltd. To date, the minister has not responded to this proposal. The proposal requires the Commonwealth to grant a lease of the site to Point Cook Operations Ltd at a peppercorn rental. What loss of revenue this could cause the Commonwealth is a matter of speculation as the Point Cook site has not been valued. Factors relevant to the valuation would need to include the following. Even among those who do not accept that the aviation strip needs to be kept for historic reasons there is an acceptance that the museum and a tightly defined heritage precinct needs to be kept, irrespective of who ends up in eventual control of the site. That is obviously something that would affect the site's value. Also affecting the site's value is the fact that significant areas need remediation because they have been used in the past for weapons testing. Also, the site is not only not sewered in terms of having a sewerage grid on the site; it is not in any way connected to the main sewerage system in metropolitan Melbourne and there is considerable cost involved with such connection.

Then there is the question of upgrading the necessary infrastructure if the site were to be devoted to housing development. For example, Point Cook Roadâthe road that links the base with the major freeway, the Princes Freewayâis in no way capable of taking extra traffic and is under standard for the volume of traffic that it currently is required to cater for. In addition, there is the need to consider the effect of the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands of International Importance. There are wetlands in the vicinity of this site. The Commonwealth has international obligations in the use of our wetlands, and the pressure of development would need to be considered against those international obligations. And relevant to the debate is the question: how do you price the heritage value of maintaining the oldest functioning aviation strip in the world and the birthplace of the RAAF? How do you value having the RAAF Museum and the RAAF Chapel maintained in a setting which is compatible with their functions? Obviously there is a real debate about this questionâa real debate about what the site should be used for, a real debate about the question of costs to the Commonwealth. It is a debate that has to be had, and it has to be managed in such a way that the aviation community, the local community and the stakeholders who currently use the Point Cook site are all consulted and embraced in that debate so we get the clearest possible picture of what should happen with the site.

As I have indicated, the consultation simply is not happening. But, almost worse than that, there has been a deliberate attempt by the Defence Estates Organisationâwhich is currently charged with managing the site with a view to its eventual disposalâa clear strategy emerging from that organisation to discourage those who currently use the site from continuing to use the site, obviously because the Defence Estates Organisation, notwithstanding the community debate about this issue, has as its eventual plan to sell as much of the site as possible for housing. The way in which this has come to my attention is that I have been approached by a number of aircraft owners and operators who were required by the Defence Estates Organisation to sign an `airfield use agreement'. They were required to sign that agreement by 29 Februaryâthis year being a leap yearâand the threat held over their heads was that if they did not sign that agreement their aircraft would have to be removed from the Point Cook site the next day. When you look at the agreement its terms are indeed outrageous. I will raise three particular issues stemming from the agreement.

Firstly, there is the question of the charges being levied to land at Point Cook. The agreement is structured so that if you want to land your aircraft at Point Cook you must enter the agreement. That costs you $260, and then you pay $10 each day that your aircraft is present at Point Cook. So a single landing by a non-commercial, single-engine aircraft would cost a grand total of $270. This compares with a total costâbecause they do not require these agreements with $260 fees in themâfor landing at Moorabbin, for example, of $7. That is, it is almost 40 times more expensive to land at Point Cook than it is to land at Moorabbin. The comparison gets more and more ridiculous because you can land your non-commercial, single-engine aircraft at Tullamarine airport or Sydney airport, even in peak periods, for $250, and for $100 off-peak; that is, it is cheaper to land your single-engine aircraft at Australia's two major airports, Tullamarine and Sydney, than it is to land at Point Cook. That is the effect of this agreement. They cannot be commercial rates. They are rates which, in my view, it cannot be denied have been struck with a view to discouraging aviators from using Point Cook, to clear the site in preparation for housing.

Secondly, these agreements provide that you need to give 48 hours notice if you want to land at Point Cook. We are talking about private aircraft operators, hobby operators, who literally look out the window on a Saturday morning and think to themselves it might be a nice day to go flying. If they want to land at Moorabbin, for example, or at Essendon or at Coolangatta or at Mangalore or any of those places, they merely are required to radio in whilst they are preparing to land to allow the aircraft controllers to make sure that there is not a problem with too many planes landing at once.

Thirdly, there is the question of risk management. Initially, the flying club that operates from there was told that each of its directorsâthis is a non-profit clubâwould have to sign an unconditional, continuing personal guarantee in order that their members could continue to fly out of Point Cook. Ultimately, that was resolved on the basis that instead of requiring those guarantees they would be asked for an additional $500 security deposit. What sort of rational, contracting structure can it be that asks for unconditional, continuing personal guarantees one day and settles for an extra $500 security deposit the next?

What the Minister for Defence needs to do in respect of the Point Cook site is put on hold any future conduct of the Defence Estates Organisation which would prejudice the interests of any of the current users of the Point Cook site and engage in a public consultation strategy about the site's future. (Time expired)

talker.name: Brough, Mal, MP
Mr BROUGH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak on probably the most important issue of our time, and that is unemployment. This issue, of course, has been uppermost in the public's minds for many years, as we saw unemployment reach records of 11.1 per cent, over one million Australians unemployed, under the previous Labor government. They had spent $2 billion on training programs, they had done all sorts of weird and wonderful things, but with one net outcome: more people were unemployed. There was less job security. There were more families out there reliant upon social security than ever before, with no hope for the future.

speech.para: Under this government we have obviously seen a major decrease in the number of unemployed and an increase, conversely, of those that are employed, those that have got jobs, those that are able to fend for themselves, to be able to look to the future. Unfortunately, my home state of Queensland under Labor Premier Peter Beattieâwho made big in the last election that he was going to reduce unemployment to five per centâhas in fact gone against the national trend. Since March 1999 across the nation we have seen unemployment go from 7.4 per cent, steadily falling through June at 7.3 per cent; August, 7.1 per cent; October, seven per cent; December 1999, 6.9 per cent; down to March of this year at 6.8 per cent. That is the trend.

We all know that unemployment figures jump around from one month to another, but what is important with these figures is the trend line. Is it going up, is it going down or is it stable? Are we providing hope to those unemployed people or are we just leaving them there on the dustbin of unemployment? The fact is that nationally the federal government has put in policies which have seen unemployment steadily coming down. It is now 0.6 per cent lower than it was in March 1999â7.4 per cent down to 6.8 per cent. The number of people unemployed has gone from 699,800 down to 651,000 peopleso, basically 700,000 down to about 650,000; 50,000 fewer unemployed people throughout the nation.

Let us contrast that with Queensland under the Beattie Labor government. They have been able to enjoy all of the benefits that this federal government has been able to put in place, but they have still managed to go against the national trend. In March 1999, eight per cent of Queenslanders were unemployed, or 142,000 Queenslanders. In March 2000, the latest figures are eight per cent unemployedâexactly the same figure but on an increased population, which means we in fact have more people in raw terms unemployed, now 145,000. So this Beattie governmentâwhich is great on dealing with the media, great on rhetoricâis in fact doing absolutely nothing of a positive nature to assist those people that generate jobs, the small business constituency.

I would like to point out a couple of reasons behind this. The first and most obvious is the reversal of the Workplace Relations Act in Queensland. One of the first things that Premier Beattie did was to say, `We will repeal the unfair dismissal laws and take away the exemption for small business.' We all know that Queensland depends entirely upon small business to generate jobs, more so than any other state in the Commonwealth. So small business are the one group that most needed to have the protection from unfair dismissal laws. A businessman spoke to me the other day, a 59-year-old man. He had never been in court in his life. He has had numerous businesses. He was confronted with an employee that he had had for three months. He had done absolutely nothing wrong. He was asked to front an unfair dismissal court. He did not lose the case, but it cost him $30,000 to defend a position which he did not even lose. The message it sent to him and all of his colleagues and friends was that this law was working against not only his business but the employment opportunities that he could provide to Queenslanders. It is simply not good enough.

But Mr Beattie is not satisfied with knocking small business. Today we have the Queensland government submission on long service leave in front of the Queensland Industrial Relations Commission. Their position is to make long service leave more generous for Queenslanders than it currently is. What does thatâan extra impost, an impost which they can ill afford at a time when Mr Beattie cannot get unemployment down one iota in the state yet we can as a federal government across the boardâdo for small business?

Then we turn to the rural sector. There are another couple of cases before the Industrial Relations Commission revolving around small business contractors in the rural sector. Shearers are obviously the backbone of the wool industryâit would not be able to survive without themâand here we have a case before the commission where the Queensland government would like to see shearers having to be employees, not employers, absolutely pulling at the cornerstone of what has been a traditional Australian industry with people with a bit of entrepreneurial spirit wanting to work harder to achieve greater incomes for their families and, therefore, greater security; and the Beattie Labor government says no.

So he turns their attention to the transport industry and attacks them in exactly the same manner and says, `Here in the transport industry we want to drive people back to being employees; we do not want them to be self-employed; maybe they will go and join the Transport Workers Union.' It is more about union membership than about people being able to look after themselves, having the self-respect of being employed. There are two other examples in both the rural and the transport industry, as well as in general small business, where the Labor government has lost the plot and in doing so is really responsible for why we have unemployment stuck at eight per cent in the state, going against the national average.

In the dairy industryâwhich is to be deregulated from 1 July; this hits very much home in my own electorateâthe federal government took the responsible role of trying to put together a deregulation package, a measure of $1.7 billion-odd to assist the deregulation of this industry. This was not federal government legislation; this is all state government legislation. The state government benefited. They received national competition policy funding to assist the restructure of these industries. But how much did the Minister for Primary Industries and Rural Communities, Mr Palaszczuk, or Premier Beattie in the Labor government put into this industry? Did they put in $10 million? Did they match Western Australia, with their $26 million or $28 million? No, they did not give one red cent, not a cent to an industry which is now on its knees and need not be if only the state government took the responsibility of protecting this vital rural sector of the Queensland economy. It is not only the dairy industry but all of the industries that flow on to it like the transport industry. They rely on the dairy industry in my area, yet they are going to lose this element of their income because the dairy industry closes.

talk.start.para: âWho deregulated? Who caused the deregulation of the dairy industry? The Liberal Party.

âThe member for Dickson sits and interjects. The member for Dicksonâwho used to be the shadow minister for regional affairs and who doesn't even visit her own regional electorate, let alone regional Australiaâwould not know what the dairy industry is going through. I would suggest to you quite strongly that you go out to the west of your electorate to Dayboro, talk to the dairy industry and find out why they are struggling. They are struggling because you and your party in the Queensland parliament have no compassion whatsoever for Queensland farmers.

âI suggest that the member opposite get a bit of a reality check. Check the facts, stop talking rhetoric and go out and meet some of those people in your electorate, Cheryl. They will be pleased to meet you. They will know what is going wrong in the electorate and why they are not being represented.

speech.para: In conclusion, it is clear here that the member for Dickson wants to prattle on loud and long because she knows as well as I do that the people of Dickson and the people of Longman are being disadvantaged by a Labor state government that is bucking the trend. It cannot stick with what is happening nationally, where we are seeing a continual reduction in unemployment. Mr BeattieâMr Five Per Centâis locked on to eight per cent unemployment, and has been for 12 months. The cold hard reality is that more Queensland families are reliant on social security, and they do not have a stable future because Queensland is being ignored by its state government. It does not have good policies for small business, but small business is the engine room of job creation in that state. Until Mr Beattie gets off his backside and starts to do something for Queensland's small business community, we will see a further erosion of employment opportunities for people in the electorates of Longman and Dickson and right throughout the Queensland region. Mr Beattie, it is not good enough to be able to put up with eight per cent unemployment for Queensland. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak about problems confronting the Australian sugar industry. Sugar production could be cut by around half a million tonnes of its potential this year, due mainly to recent flooding and cyclone damage in North Queensland. These problems have been compounded by the slump in world sugar prices, which tumbled to a 14-year low last year, and a range of pest and disease problems. The combination of all these factors is likely to produce the third consecutive year of disastrously low returns.

speech.para: The Australian sugar industry is one of the world's largest and most reliable exporters of high quality sugar and the production of raw sugar is one of Australia's most important rural industries. Each year the sugar industry usually contributes, directly and indirectly, about $4.5 billion to the economy. Sugar is Australia's fourth largest export earning agricultural industry, accounting for 6.8 per cent of the total value of farm exports and 22 per cent of crop product exports. Thus the decline in the world sugar price not only has an impact on the sugar industry's revenue but also affects our nation's trade. Sugar is the most important rural industry in Queensland, which produces 95 per cent of Australia's sugar. It underpins the economic stability of many communities along the Queensland coast, including Bundaberg and Childers in my electorate. The Queensland Sugar Corporation estimates that the state's production in 2000 will be around five million tonnes. The industry's peak grower organisation, the Canegrowers, is less optimistic, expecting a figure somewhat below that.

This year is widely regarded in the industry as one of the most atrocious on record. World sugar prices plummeted last year to less than US5c a pound, brought about by the sixth year of global oversupply and a devaluation of the Brazilian real. Returns to Australian cane growers for raw sugar collapsed to an estimated $250 a tonne from $392 a tonne in mid-1998. The expectation is that that could fall even further this year to a new low of around $200 a tonneâa frightening thought for people in my electorate. In a recent press release the General Manager of Canegrowers, Ian Ballantyne, said that a mediocre cane crop last year, combined with the fall in the world sugar price, had cost the Queensland industry more than $500 million in lost income. The total revenue for Queensland sugar producers is likely to be around $1.1 billion this year, a drop of nearly half the revenue of 1997, when the industry experienced a record production of 5.5 million tonnes.

The North Queensland sugar industry is facing severe financial hardship following damage from cyclonic winds and flooding. Some growers have experienced four cyclones in four years and others have experienced flooding six times. The physical damage to the crops and the sugar content means that growers between Townsville and Mossman are virtually guaranteed a poor crop this season. There are three factors at play here, as you would well know, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, coming from a sugar area: your crop, the CCSâcommercial content of sugarâand the price you get for your sugar. In North Queensland they had the worst of all worlds. Because of the cyclonic conditions, they have a poor crop in volume, a very poor CCS and, on top of that, record low international prices. That is like a triple whammyâthe worst of all thingsâand it does demand government attention.

The downturn has not only affected growers along the coast but also had a serious impact on the milling sector through reduced cane supply, wet weather delays to crushing and a substantial fall in income. We have heard that some mills are now in serious financial difficulties. The Australian sugar industry is world competitive and can normally stand on its own feet, but the circumstances facing the industry are now beyond its control. The government has made available $13.5 million over four years for research in the sugar industry. However, I deeply feel that the industry also needs some form of assistance by way of a package to help it deal with the operational and seasonal problems it is now facing. A replanting would be one option, for example.

I think we need to look at removing some of the barriers that can limit access to schemes like exceptional circumstance and national disaster assistance. These programs tend to cover drought related problems which can devastate farmers over a long period of time. However, the situation facing North Queensland cane growers has shown that wet weather can be just as problematic as dry weather. Another option that I think the government needs to consider is extending the Farm Family Restart Scheme in not only scope but also time. It delivers improved welfare support to the farm sector. This is a commendable scheme that has assisted many farmers, but perhaps its scope could be widened and its time extended. I make the observation that when you look at the notional values of farms $500 million sounds like a lot of money, but when you have two or three families trying to exit a farm like that perhaps the limit is too small. Perhaps it should be up around $650 million to $750 million.

In my electorate, cane growers have not had to face harsh, wet conditions and have been producing excellent crops with high sugar content. That has really assisted the Bundaberg district, albeit they have suffered with the low price of sugar on the international market. However, the low price of sugar on the international market has had an adverse impact on growers, and this can subsequently impact on jobs and investment in the regionâsomething that it can ill afford. In recent weeks, the Bundaberg sugar industry has been experiencing a different problem from that faced in the north, and this is too much dry weather. This raises a potential problem for the Bundaberg region. If drought conditions occurring in the future are combined with the low sugar price, the problems of economic viability now being faced in North Queensland could surface in the Bundaberg-Childers area as well.

The critical issue in the Bundaberg region is certainly that of waterânot of too much water but of water itself. Cane production varies due to rainfall and available irrigation. We are at the centre of the Bundaberg irrigation scheme, one of the most intensive in Australia. Over the last 10 years, the crop has ranged from 2.35 million tonnes to 3.8 million tonnes last year, with an average of 3.2 million tonnes. Bundaberg cane farmers have not been prolifigate in their use of waterâin fact, they lead the state in water efficiency in cane productionâbut are limited by the unreliable and inadequate irrigation supply. The area of cane irrigated with trickle systems has increased from 1,200 hectares across the district in 1995 to 3,600 in 1999. That is a remarkable growth, as I am sure you would agree, Mr Deputy Speaker. However, there are limitations in extending beyond this level. For example, converting to trickle irrigation requires an investment of $155,000 for a 50-hectare farm, and there is no assurance that this investment will provide a return, given particularly the supply of water, which I just talked about, and the low sugar prices.

A new dam has been proposed at Paradise, west of my electorate, in the electorate of Wide Bay. A dam costing $150 million would deliver 203,000 megalitres of water. The impact that this could have on the district is very significant. It could create 2.2 million tonnes of cane on existing land and 2.7 on new landâjust under five million extra tonnes of cane. That translates into 711,000 tonnes of sugar. The return could be around $177 million, even on the low prices we are experiencing at present, which comes down to about $150 million worth of exports. In times of better world sugar prices, these figures could be $50 million or $60 million higher. You can see the impact it could have on the region.

The urgent need for the new dam was highlighted recently by the announcement of a feasibility study into a billion dollar integrated industrial development in the Bundaberg region. Multiplex, Bundaberg Sugar and Contact Energy are investigating the feasibility of establishing a bagasse pulp plant, power plant and a synthetic rutile plant adjacent to an existing Bundaberg sugar mill. This project would not only improve the productivity and profitability of the sugar cane industry but give a substantial boost to the region's economy, creating up to 600 jobs. I understand that all sectors of the industry are worried by this, and I urge federal government ministers, who will meet representatives of the various sectors of the industry next week, to give their case every consideration. (Time expired)

debateinfo.title: HEALTH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (GAP COVER SCHEMES) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 15 March, on motion by Dr Wooldridge:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âThis is an adjourned debate on the Health Legislation Amendment (Gap Cover Schemes) Bill 2000 from 15 March. At that time the House was addressed by the member for Curtin, Ms Julie Bishop. She engaged in what has now become a favourite pastime of the Liberal Partyâthe total rewriting of the history of health policy in this country. The member for Curtin strikes me as one of those pompous, born to rule types who are shoehorned into the parliament by the tory party in this country, and part of their mandate, born to rule, is to rewrite political history and policy making history as they see it. She cannot be allowed to get away with that. The House needs to bring these people to account and get the history right before we can move on to sound solutions in health policy. This is what the member for Curtin said on 15 March:

quote.para: ... our public health system needs a viable private health system to survive.

speech.para: Then she went on to talk about the fundamental principle of Medicare:

quote.para: Its long-term viability was predicated on the basis of a strong and viable private health insurance component as part of the overall health landscape.

speech.para: The first question to ask is: how would she know? She was never one of the people doing the hard policy work in the 1960s to devise Medibank and then Medicare. She was never in the public policy laboratory developing a public health insurance system for this country. She was one of those tories trying to blow up the lab. She was one of those tories outside protesting with placards, one of those tories voting time and again against the introduction of public health insurance for all Australians. So how would she know about the principles upon which Medibank and Medicare have been based?

She is arguing from a position of ignorance, she is arguing without information and the facts, and she is totally wrong. I am going to use the source that is the definitive account of the development of Medibank. You go to the maker. Don't mess around with these phoney, born to rule tories. Go to the maker of Medibank, and it is Dick Scotton, along with John Deeble. To his great credit, Scotton has produced this wonderful book, The Making of Medibank. This is what he has to say about private health insurance on page 63, talking about the period of the Whitlam government:

quote.para: The hospital services working party also worked on proposals relating to private hospitals and on the private insurance arrangements which would apply after the introduction of Medibank. Deeble and Scotton arguedâon equity and practical groundsâfor private hospital subsidies at levels comparable to the per diem value of the payments for private patients in public hospitals. Under the universal program the main function of private insurance would be the provision of benefits to reimburse the (substantially reduced) fees charged to private patients.
Given that the private health funds would no longer be handling any public moneyâ

speech.para: unlike todayâ

quote.para: Scotton and Deeble believed that the regulatory framework should be substantially dismantled, subject only to requirements for solvency and minimum coverage standards. They also believed that their reserves should be run down before the implementation of the public program to levels commensurate with the diminished scale of their operations.

speech.para: There is no doubt that the makers of Medibank and Medicare envisaged private health insurance as a residual system, as totally and fundamentally residual to public health care in this country. There was none of this nonsense we have heard from the member for Curtin and her colleagues about the success of the public system being based on the long-term viability of private health insurance. Private health insurance under Medibank and Medicare was always envisaged as a residual system. The first task for government was to put the money where it was needed most, into public hospitals and public services, and then to allow private health insurance to find its own equilibrium, to find its own balance without a great deal of government regulationâno community rating, for instanceâand certainly without huge public subsidies. There was never any plan for the massive public subsidisation of private health insurance.

The member for Curtin is thoroughly wrong. She should climb down from her born to rule pedestal and give the House the facts instead of absolutely fabricated nonsense. How can we conduct an important debate about the future of the Australian health system if we do not deal with the facts? The member for Curtin reminds me of Senator Payne: an idiot in search of a villageâanother Liberal fabricating information, totally without the facts. The House should deal with the proper information. The truth of the matter is that private health insurance should be a residual system operating like any other market. It should be returned to its residual role, like any other market. It should not have these enormous public subsidies. The money should be sent to the point of greatest need, and that is the public system.

It is a test of commonsense. Where do you get the best value for moneyâsubsidising private insurance, which many young and healthy Australians may never use, or putting the public money into quality public hospitals where sick people desperately need the services and where many Australians need a reduction in public hospital waiting lists? The pattern of pumping up the private sector at the expense of the public sector defies not only commonsense but international experience. In no part of the world is there any sort of equilibrium between public and private health shares. The golden rule of good policy making is to get the core services right, and those core services are in public hospitals and other parts of the public system. Then, policy makers can worry about private insurance.

Public money should not be going into optional insurance. It should be going into the basic services. The legislation now before the House continues this government's failed approach to health policy. It continues to try and pump up the viability of the private sector at the expense of public sector services. The bill continues a failed pattern of health reform under the Howard government. This legislation tries to make private insurance more attractive by covering the gaps. But the question needs to be asked: at what cost? Gap insurance takes the brakes off medical expenses. It adds to the inflationary impact of the private sector. It continues the government's pattern of trying to boost the finances of the private sector at the expense of public health outlays. It continues the pattern in Australia where private medical expenses are far outstripping the CPI whereas public costs and outlays are well below the rate of inflation.

It is difficult to see how the bill can be amended to contain medical costs. In fact, this is one of the constitutional limits with which policy makers in this country need to live. Unfortunately, in 1949 the Chifley government had its legislation struck down where it was trying to apply the principle of a limit on medical costs. The High Court, in a remarkable decision, found that it would be civil conscriptionâoutlawed under the Constitutionâto prohibit a doctor from prescribing medicines specified in a formula otherwise than on a prescription form supplied by the Commonwealth, even though the prohibition did not apply when the patient requested the doctor not to write the prescription on the form. That was the case of British Medical Association v. the Commonwealth in 1949.

There is a constitutional prohibition as interpreted by the High Court on the capacity of this parliament to limit private medical expenses. But, as I pointed out in another context, the Constitution should not be used as an alibi for inaction but rather an invitation for innovation. Unfortunately, however, we do not see a great deal of innovation in Australian health policy. There is a constant pattern of cost shifting between levels of government and, with that, blame shifting as federal and state administrations try to convince the public that someone else is to blame for the inadequacies of this system. There is a pattern of incremental reform, just tinkering at the edges, not getting to the structural problems in the Australian health system. We have, prompted by this government, a tug of war between public and private resource shares.

We need to face the fact that the Australian health system is fundamentally broken. It is characterised by overlapping programs and responsibilities. It is characterised by a great deal of federal-state inefficiency in the way in which basic services have been organised. It is characterised by the underutilisation of the enormous technological possibilities of the information age as applied to health care. It is characterised by terribly inequitable regional imbalances in the allocation of health resources. This is part of a broader malaise in our political system. Often we hear members in this place asked: why does the public have so little faith in parliament? Why was it once an honoured profession to be a public representative and now it has all the public status of a used car salesman?

You do not need a PhD to work out the answer to that question. The parliament is obsessed with the minutiae of process while the public is only interested in the depth of solutions. This place has overdosed on processâthe process of blaming each other for problems old and new, the process of perpetual short-termism, responding to the daily news agenda, the process of avoiding risk and putting solutions off to yet another day. This charade is played out in full in the development of health policy. We have the charade of federal and state governments blaming each other for structural problems in the system. We have posturing designed only to please the daily news media.

All this tinkering at the edges means that policy making rarely gets to the heart of structural problems and structural solutions. So, against that background, it is not surprising that the health system lurches from one crisis to another and that the average Australian has very little confidence in the capacity of this parliament to get sustainable answers.

But I believe some answers are available. I referred earlier to the work of Dick Scotton, the co-maker of Medibank and Medicare. He has a plan for strengthening Medicareâhe calls it Medicare Plus. This breaks the insoluble dilemma in Australian health policy, to try to simultaneously achieve three outcomes: first, to maintain universal health insurance and health care; secondly, to ensure a fair distribution of health resources between social groups and also locations; and, finally, to limit the outrageous growth of medical expenses.

It is true that Medicare has been a fine system, but even with its fine design it is not able to achieve that third goal of limiting the growth of medical expenses. While Medicare has been a good way of financing health insurance, the organisation of health services around it has become second rate. The federal government alone runs 60 separate health programs, each with its own rules and funding arrangements. On top of this, the states and territories have their own array of programs and funding rules. The system resembles a dog's breakfast. While public services such as nursing homes and public hospitals have been capped in their budgets and face a shortage of funds, private services such as GP and pharmaceuticals have unlimited access to the federal budget. You would not organise any other part of the public sector, and certainly not the corporate sector, in this fashion. This has caused the problem of cost shifting, where the states try to close down services in public hospitals and push their costs onto the federal government. As with most fights between government, it is only the public which suffers.

Even worse, health funding has been slow to follow shifts in population, leaving areas like the south-west of Sydney, including my electorate, hopelessly underresourced. Too much money is being soaked up by private health costs and the anticompetitive practices of medical specialists. It is my fear that this legislation, the Gap Cover Scheme, will add to that particular problem.

Each of these issues has weakened the success of Medicare. Health reform in Australia has become essential, not to replace Medicare but to save it from slow and steady decline, such as the last four years under the Howard government. This is where Dick Scotton's modern thinking comes in. He has developed a way of keeping the strengths of Medicare-free public hospitals, bulk-billing GPs and cheap pharmaceuticals, while also creating greater choice for consumers and improved efficiency.

The concept is quite simple. Every Australian resident would be allocated government funds to cover their basic health insurance, weighted to reflect their exposure to health risks. The elderly and chronically ill, for instance, would receive much more due to their greater use of health services. It is a weighted capitation amount to meet the health insurance needs of every Australian resident. People would then be able to choose from a range of insurance options. They could either stay with a government insurer and their current Medicare coverage or choose a non-government insurer, topping up their public allocation with their own money to secure a wider insurance coverage. All public and private insurers would be brought into the one system. These competing health insurers would contract with private and public care providers to guarantee the best service for their members.

Scotton's proposals end the problem of cost shifting by pooling health resources under the federal government. The states would be responsible for the management of public insurance plans and public health services. Private services would be fully integrated into the national health program. This fulfils the original vision of Medibank, for these private services to play a residual role, in this case integrated into the national health program. This is the best way of controlling private costs and at long last ensuring that doctors are fully accountable to their patients.

This is where the Scotton plan has so many advantages over this particular piece of legislation. It achieves the third leg, what hitherto has been the unattainable third leg, in Australian health policyâthat is, to limit the outrageous growth of private medical expenses. Scotton has developed a system where at long last doctors would work for the community, instead of the current system where the public purse is put to work by the doctors. Under the Scotton plan, health consumers would have a major say in the way services are run, particularly at a local level. The plan makes this possible by getting them involved in the governance of health insurance and community health schemes. It also ensures that government funding follows consumers and their needs, rather than the medical profession and its needs. This approach would give underresourced regions their fair share of the health dollar.

I commend this particular plan to the House. As I pointed out earlier, we have too much incremental reform and short-term analysis of health issues in this country. We need to take a longer view. We need to be optimistic about our chances, notwithstanding the constitutional restriction, of realising those three health goalsâuniversal health insurance, the fair distribution of health resources in different parts of the country and the placement of some sort of reasonable cap in the growth of private medical expenses.

These things are achievable, but just as Medibank and Medicare were not introduced through incremental policy making so too now we require a bold approach. Tinkering around with the public and private shares, reforming the Medicare levy and pursuing greater regulation of different parts of the health system are all incremental measures, patch-up jobs, which do a disservice to the health needs of the Australian public. Some of them, of course, have merit, but the greatest merit for this parliament is to take the longer view in health policy.

This is an Australian health system in crisis. It is an Australian health system with chronic problems that require big, structural solutions. In this particular debate, we do not find those solutions. It is another incremental piece of policy making to introduce the gap cover, another attempt by this government to tinker at the edges and try to patch up its favoured part of the health system, private health insurance.

I return to my first point: the last thing we need in these debates is a rewriting of history. We need a factual analysis, not the sort of nonsense that was presented to the parliament by the member for Curtin and, I am sure, earlier in the debate by her colleagues. We need the longer view. Dick Scotton is a health economist who takes that view of policy makingâa big, structural solution to the chronic problems in the Australian health system. I certainly commend his plan to the parliament.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak on the Health Legislation Amendment (Gap Cover Schemes) Bill 2000. I am very happy to be speaking on yet another forward initiative of this government in the area of private health insurance.

speech.para: I seem to follow the member for Latham quite a lot. I do not disagree with a lot of what he says: there is cost shifting, there are problems in the system, there are areas that are duplicated at a federal and state level and it is a health system that perhaps does not match its resources in the best possible way. These are problems that have existed for many, many years, and many governments have grappled with them on many occasions, including the member for Latham's government.

There are crazy situations that arise in healthâfor example, in Queensland, where major hospitals are opened and there are no patients. It is like something out of a Yes, Minister serial. A major teaching hospital in my electorate, the Prince Charles Hospital, is the leading cardiac hospital in the Southern Hemisphere but it does not have an MRI machine. Currently, the administration of that hospital is talking to the state Minister for Health, Wendy Edmond, about that situation, and I will continue to lobby for an MRI machine in that hospital.

The situation is that we do have the best health system for the most affordable price. I know the member for Latham is a well-known economist and he quoted the work of Scotton, who has dealt extensively in this area, but the system is supply driven. There is nothing that we can do that can stop the supply. People still go to their GP for a variety of ailments. I thought I understood health until I became involved with someone in the medical profession a few years ago. There are people out there in the community who will go to a GP just to get a bandaid for a cut on a finger, so to not look at supply and demand is clearly a mistake when we encounter this debate.

The bill tonight looks at a number of consumer and health industry issues, and I will touch on those in a moment. I would like to point out that this government has done much and achieved more for average Australians in terms of accessibility of private health insurance than has been achieved in the history of the health insurance industry in this country. The bill complements a lot of other good measures undertaken by this government in the area of private health insurance, and the 30 per cent rebate and the move to Lifetime Health Cover are examples of this government's commitment to better value health insurance for consumers and a strong and viable private health insurance system.

The bill is particularly significant in that it vastly increases the choices and options available to private health consumers. This is the first time that legislation has been introduced to formally enable a non-contractual agreement between doctors and health funds on pricing and payment strategies for dealing with the gap. The most common health issue that my constituents come to see me about is the gap. The fact is that they go in to have a major operation and do not know how much gap is involved, and then they get a multitude of bills from the hospital and receive a huge shock after they have had their operation. I think this bill goes a long way to deal with a lot of those uncertainties and a lot of those fears that people face at the end of an operation.

Indeed, valuable contributions towards addressing the gap cover issue have come from a number of private health insurers, hospitals and the AMA. It is a great example of what really can be achieved when industries get together and work with the government to facilitate and improve delivery of services to the consumer.

The bill also provides for an extensive range of health funds to develop their own gap cover schemes as well as to tailor gap cover schemes to suit individualsâa measure which vastly increases the choice to each private health cover consumer. The gap schemes are voluntary and ensure no inflationary impactâthat is, they do not provide for open-ended reimbursement of medical fees, nor do they increase the total cost for consumers. Most importantly, the interests and the welfare of consumers are completely safeguarded. In fact, all gap cover schemes will need to be approved by the Minister for Health and Aged Care before they can be implemented, and that ensures that they will remain fair and genuine in their benefits to consumers. Other ways in which the aims and intentions of the gap cover bill are safeguarded are in the balance and the fairness to the consumer, the industry and the medical profession. They will generally deliver no gaps or, if chosen, known gaps to consumers, and that is very important.

The member who spoke previously spoke about the role of the GP in this. I think the GP has a very valuable role to play in ensuring that patients know what costs are incurred when they are admitted to hospital and that they have full financial consent and full financial information relating to those costs. It is not uncommon to hear in my electorate about someone with the top level of cover in private health insurance going in for heart surgery and having to pay a bill of $30,000. In fact, I was speaking to the Mayor of Redcliffe some months back when he told me how much his heart surgery cost him. Those situations will no longer occur under this legislation. People will have financial consent. They will be able to make a decision to go to those particular doctors who have no-gap products, and they will have greater choice available to them.

The provisions contained within this scheme will ensure that, in the event that the scheme is revoked by the minister, the consumers are in no way disadvantaged. Also, the scheme requires medical practitioners to inform private health insurance consumers of any amount that they will be liable to pay for a professional procedure. That is a very important part of the doctor-patient relationship and should never be compromised as well. Patients should be informed of how much their operation or procedure is going to cost them. Doctors currently do that. They currently advise patients of specialists who do charge the prescribed amount and no more. It already exists, but I think this bill will provide greater scope for that to occur.

The scheme also provides for simple billing arrangements and streamlining of an individual's claim procedure by providing one bill for all-in-one hospital cost. It is not unusual for people to go into hospital and be presented with 50 bills. It is pretty horrifying. Even when you go into hospital for a minor operation, you can have something like 10 or 15 bills by the time pathology, X-rays, pharmaceuticals, et cetera are sent to you. It can be daunting. Just when you think you are over one hurdleâpaying one amount to the radiologistâanother bill will come in and set you on that sort of horror train of more financial imposts. Perhaps most importantly the schemes will be reviewed at regular intervals to absolutely ensure that the above criteria are adhered to, and the minister has the power to revoke any scheme that is not delivering a better method and better outcomes to patients.

The bill will also provide the best deal for average Australians who have, or would like to take out, private health insurance, and the bill is good for medical practitioners as well. The issue of gap cover has been, to date, a problematic one, and it has been a problematic one for a number of sectors, including the medical profession. However, this bill ensures that all gap cover schemes maintain and guarantee the professional freedom of medical practitioners, and that freedom should never be compromised. Indeed, since we made amendments back in 1997 whereby doctors could come to contractual arrangements on hospital based gap cover, the number of patients being covered by gap products and the number of hospital admissions being covered by gap products has increased by approximately 25 per cent in the December quarter of 1999 alone. This bill is a further improvement on these existing arrangements.

The gap has long proved to be a thorn in the side of the private health insurance industry and is the single most important factor in the public perception of private health insurance as not value for money. Quite often, members of parliament deal with constituents who question that value for money, and I think that this legislation goes a long way to addressing some of those particular problems. Consumers essentially want no gap, or at least they want a known gap, in return for their insurance premiums. The continued existence of the gap is the major cause of complaint about private health insurance, and it has been the major cause of complaint of my constituents over the last four years. It particularly occurs when there is a requirement to pay and it is not realised by the patient prior to the receipt of the bill for services. This difficulty has obviously impacted on the participation by the general population in private health insurance. National private health insurance coverage has fallen from 61.5 per cent of the Australian population in 1983 to just over 30 per cent in December 1999. That was an alarming drop and it needed to be addressed because the increasing number of people who drop off from private health insurance places a greater demand and a greater stress and strain on the public system. We need to address those issues.

Each year, private health insurance contributes around $3 billion in hospital benefits, and the private sector cares for about one-third of all hospital patients annually. It is clear that private health insurance plays a crucial role in funding the hospital system in this country. It is not an area that we can allow to fall behind, and the Labor Party let it fall behind with disastrous results. Any fall in the proportion of people covered in the private health systemâa fall such as we experienced under Laborâhas far-reaching implications for the Australian health system as a whole. The Howard government has sought to turn this tide around with significant results; the participation rate has begun to rise again, and that is a good thing. With the introduction of the initiatives of the 30 per cent rebate and Lifetime Health Cover, the government has put private health cover back on track. The bill seeks to enhance and improve upon that record. It is also designed to make private health insurance good value for money again. It makes it transparent, streamlined and up front, and it represents the government's hard work and absolute commitment to a robust, fair and efficient health insurance industry.

There are problems in the health system; there are problems of resources and there have been from time immemorial. There are problems with federal and state governments. There are problems of cost shifting, as we spoke about earlier, and they need to be addressed in time. There are a number of programs that are duplicated. But there are times when federal and state governments can and do work together well. I had an opportunity recently to launch a domestic violence initiative that came under this particular portfolio area where the federal government provided the funding and the state government was able to implement the program, which dealt particularly with young children and the effects of domestic violence on them.

The health system is the best health system when one compares it to those in many other countries in the world and their difficulties and lack of resources. One of the things that people do not realise or perhaps are not informed about is the cost of pharmaceuticals. They feel it is a free health care system and that pharmaceuticals, for example, are free as well. A number of my constituents are quite amazed when I speak to them about the cost of pharmaceuticals, the fact that the government picks up the tab for pharmaceuticals and that they are not solely costed at $2.60âfor example, some heart and high blood pressure tablets can cost up to $100 and the government picks up the tab for that under the best pharmaceutical benefits scheme in the world. Our drugs are 30 per cent to 40 per cent cheaper than anywhere else in the world.

One should not lose sight of the great health system that we do have. We have an affordable health care system. Anyone today can go to a GP and take advantage of the bulk-billing system. Sure, it is abused. There are cases where people do doctor shop. They do abuse medications. I know that before the prescribed minimum amount of pharmaceuticals was brought in there were members of the communityâand this occurred largely in the aged populationâwho would go to the chemist for their free pharmaceuticals and stockpile them. The pharmaceuticals would run past their use-by date and there was a tremendous waste of resources in stockpiling pharmaceuticals that were never ever used. It was a problem.

We have a good health care system. We have a health care system that is available for all peopleâthe Medicare system and bulk-billing. We have a great pharmaceutical system and integrity of GPs. I must also commend the minister for the training initiatives, particularly in the GP area. The profession asked for those particular initiatives and we delivered them, and the quality of training of our GPs is one of the highest in the world and we are recognised as leaders in the medical profession universally.

This bill represents the government's hard work and absolute commitment to having that robust, fair and efficient private health insurance industry. It will mean that the private health industry and people who have private health insurance do get value for money. It will make sure that they have a known-gap product, that they know what they are going to pay when they go into hospital. The GP also has a valuable role in this in providing informed consent and providing assistance in letting patients know just what that gap or what those medical expenses will be, and that will mean that there will be greater peace of mind. I know that this private health insurance bill that I speak to tonight will provide a fair and more efficient system. I commend the bill to the House.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.26 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âThe House is considering the Health Legislation Amendment (Gap Cover Schemes) Bill 2000.
