talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 14 March 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Government's intention to use socio-economic data drawn from Census collector districts to determine the distribution of non-government school funding.
(2) Is the current method for the distribution of the various components of childcare funding equitable on the basis of socio-economic status.
(3) Will the Minister apply the methodology referred to in part (1) to childcare funding.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes, I am aware of the Government's intention to use socio-economic data drawn from the Census collector districts to determine the distribution of non-government school funding.

(2) One of the key principals on which childcare funding is based is that it is targeted to low and middle income families. Child care is an essential element in the range of Government assistance available to Australian families with young children. Child care funding allows low and middle income families with young children access to a greater range of options and to help them to balance their work and family responsibilities.

Childcare Assistance is a means-tested payment made directly to child care serviceson behalf of low and middle income families and subsidises the child care fee. Services charge families the difference between their fee and the Childcare Assistance a family is eligible for, based on family income and number of children in care.

Childcare Rebate is for families using formal or informal (relatives, friends) care for work-related purposes including studying, training and looking for work and provides a rebate of 30% of the family's out of pocket child care expenses. Families with income greater than the Family Tax Initiative cutoffs ($70,000 for one child) receive a rebate of 20%.

Further evidence of the Government's commitment to equitably distribute childcare funding can be demonstrated through analysis of data based on the SEIFA Index of Relative Socio-Economic Disadvantage. This data shows that long day care centre openings are evenly spread across advantaged and disadvantaged areas.
(3) No, the Government will not be applying the proposed methodology for funding non-government schools to child care funding.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 1999:

quote.para: What sum and other assistance has the Australian Government given in relief to the famine afflicted people of North Korea.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Since 1995, Australia has provided $19.5 million in emergency humanitarian assistance including $6 million in 1999/2000.
The 1999/2000 contribution reflects a shift from emergency feeding to a broader focus on food security, disaster mitigation and environmental protection issues and includes:
- $5 million for food-for-work activities through the World Food Programme (WFP);
- $500,000 for health activities through the International Federation of the Red Cross (IFRC);
- $250,000 for vitamins and mineral supplementation through the United Nations Children Fund (UNICEF), and
-$250,000 for a tuberculosis control program through the World Health Organisation (WHO).

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Taxation Office: Cannington, Western Australia
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1271)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 March 2000:

quote.para: (1) Are 80 new staff about to be employed in the fuel excise area of the Australian Taxation Office and based at Cannington, WA.
(2) Did the decision to close the Cannington office and move the operation to Northbridge include consideration of the housing of these additional staff.
(3) Is space limited at the Northbridge site; if so, what provisions for accommodation have been made.

talk.start.para: âThe Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) An additional 80 staff are to be employed in the fuel excise area of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) in Perth. The location of these new staff in the Perth area is yet to be determined.

(2) The decision to close the Cannington office when the lease expires in May 2002 and consolidate into the Northbridge building took into account staffing projections for the Perth region, including growth related to Tax Reform.

(3) When the existing layouts within the Northbridge building are reconfigured the overall capacity of the building will be significantly increased. In addition, the ATO may acquire additional short term space to provide staging accommodation for the reconfiguration of Northbridge and to meet the short term needs of Tax Reform.
